intro: Synaphea boyaginensis, commonly known as the Western Australian sandblow, is a rare and endemic species found in the sandy soils of Western Australia. It is a low-growing shrub with small, needle-like leaves that are adapted to reduce water loss in its arid environment. The plant produces small, pale yellow flowers that bloom in late spring, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Its fibrous roots help stabilize the soil, making it ecologically significant in its habitat. Due to habitat loss, it is considered vulnerable and requires conservation efforts to ensure its survival.
